To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

23 Julij
1591
. M
r
Bodeley to my L./.
The states awnswere for shipping to meete with
e Indian fleete./

fied to my LL. in
at answear w
ch
I sent
e
13 of this moneth,
e Countes autoritie would
not stretche to

it was a mater of great expense, and required
e resolution of
e
General states
, who then
resided at
e Hage. Albeit I had no charge
to solicite
e states in
at behalf, and Count Mau-
rices answear had put me cleane out of hope,
of speeding in my motion, yet because I per-
ceaved, that nothing could be done but by
meanes of
e states, I addressed fourth with a
letter unto them, requesting both
e Count and
e
Councel of state
to doe
e like. Howbeit
before o
r
letters came unto them,
e whole
assembly of
e states were comming to this
towne, whereby
e letters were undelivered.
But I dealt w
t
them heere, assoone as they
came, omitting nothing that I thought might
drawe them forward to doe somwhat. Their
answear unto me was
e same in effect, as I
receaved of Count Maurice. That they had no
shippes of
at burden
at was proposed: That
e shortnes of time would permitte them to doe
nothing: That w
t
out
e privitie and warrant
of
e Provinces, w
ch
could not be procured under
fower or five weekes, they could take no reso-
lution: That they doubted therein
e inclina-
tion of
e Provinces, by reason of this warre
fol.252v
that is so burdensome unto them, as they are eve-
ry day forced to extraordinary charges, having
gathered this yere very great contributions,
aswell for
e augmentation of their forces, as
for
e assistance of
France
w
t
mony and other-
wise. This was
yet
it in substance whiche
they signified unto me, wherein they were so
setled, as no replie would prevaile: w
ch
I humbly
beseeche yo
w
, occasion requiring, to report unto
e LL. They have nowe made
an ende of their long consultation about the
course of their trafficke, aswell w
t
e Enemie
elswhere, as in
Spaine.
I have not seene it as
yet, nor it is not yet fully sette downe in wri-
ting: but they are busied still about
it
and when
it is finished, they will exhibit it unto me.
Heere is nothing yet resolved about
e next
imploiment of o
r
forces: w
ch
will depend
altogether upon
e Enemies courses, of whiche
nothing more is knowen then I signified in
my last, of his encamping by
Nieumeghen.
The bruite doth yet continewe of his goinge for
France, w
ch
is hardly beleved of many men
heere: for that then it is thought, he should leese
undoubtedly both Nieumeghen and
Bosleduke
and leave many other places for a praye to o
r
army, w
ch
might happely occasion a general
revolt. There is a speeche at this p
nt
,
that
Verdugo
shall returne towardes
Groenin-
ghen
w
t
his former forces, and a further ren-
forcement. The mutins of
Diest
and
Herentals
doe persist in their mutinie, as we
are advertised. Suche among them as have
fol.253r
made incursions into
Liege,
and spoiled
e con-
trey, upon
e intercession of
e clergy of Liege,
are excommunicat by
e
Pope.
Wherupon the
mutins, besides
at pay w
ch
they have hitherto
demaunded, require to be absolved of
e fore-
said excommunication, w
ch
they refuse to re-
ceave, and precisely stand upon it, unles it
be confirmed by
e Popes owne hand.
Upon a general reviewe that is made of this
campe, as it lieth nowe by
Arnham,
they
are founde to be 7200 footemen and 1600
horse, no absents nor sicke, nor hurt persons
accounted. There is also expected an aug-
mentation of their footmen, from divers of their
garrisons.
Knowing no other mater worthy
e advertisment, I take my humble leave.
From Arnham. July 23 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
